metadata.title: A Step by Step Guide to Getting Your Baseline Algorithm | by Alison Bunce | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: A Step by Step Guide to Getting Your Baseline Algorithm
metadata.description: Identify your business goal. Our most successful goals (that drive the most value) are measurable, actionable, viable and directly impact the business. For instance, a good initial goal would be to…

all_paragraphs: Identify your business goal. Our most successful goals (that drive the most value) are measurable, actionable, viable and directly impact the business. For instance, a good initial goal would be to “Let’s build an algorithmic model that helps us identify bad customers and good customers when assessing future customers for our business”. Let’s assume we have a data dictionary that defines the criteria for both a potentially good and potentially bad customer.

Establish your evaluation criteria. What metric is going to provide us with the insight we need in order to accomplish our business goal? For instance, “We want to measure the metric of how accurate our algorithm is?”

Pull your data from whichever source (that’s a process in it of itself and not the basis for this particular article). Once you’ve successfully imported your files, observe the amount of columns you have, the amount of rows, what your column names are, etc. Taking a closer look, examine the individual column names, is it clear what kind of data you’re looking at? Why or why not? Start with a high level conceptual look at your data before you begin to dig into specifics. It is important to have an idea of how everything is connected, even if you find your data to be particularly ‘dirty’ or unclear.

Identify if it’s numerical or categorical. What are your variable types? Is it normally distributed? If data is categorical, is your data ordinal or nominal? If your data is numerical, are your numerical values discrete or continuous? I recommend noting this info, in your Jupyter Notebook for instance, by commenting it out (with the #comment here).

Identify if your data has any outliers. In order to make proper calculations on your data, you’ll need to normalize it as closely as you can. Getting rid of extraneous data points will help your data structure from being too skewed.
Identify missing values (if any). Typically we use the mean, sometimes median or mode to give us the best values to fill in any blanks within our dataset.

Split the data either 80/20 or 75/25 where 80% or 75% is your training set and 20% or 25% is your test set. You don’t want to train your algorithm on everything you have- your algorithm needs fresh, raw data to test from. We use the sample to test the model on something new (the model has not seen this data before). We establish our predictive results based on the training dataset. By comparing our predictive results to test dataset, we can measure the true strength of the algorithm.
Normalize and ‘clean’ the training data. Fill in missing values, remaining outliers to help normalize the data so you can properly work with it.

Normalize and ‘clean’ the test data. While this method can be viewed as more tedious, it is considered best practice to clean your test data set separate from your training data set — it helps you avoid overfitting. Overfitting is an error that occurs in your model when your predictive data is too closely fit to your historic data.

Modeling Phase. Determine which types of model, which is contingent upon which machine learning type we seek to apply. We ask ourselves, is it a classification problem, regression problem, or unsupervised learning problem?
Once determined, implement the model. Here you can pick 3–4 different algorithms that fall within your ‘problem type’.
Classification: Random Forest, Naive Bayes, Logistic Regression, Gradient Boosting, K-Nearest Neighbors.

Regression: Ridge, Lasso, Elastic, Net, Linear, Non-Linear, (these algorithms are not to be confused with the classification algorithms, as they are Regression algorithms- Random Forest Regressor, Gradient Boosting Regressor, K-Nearest Neighbors Regressor).

Unsupervised Learning: Dimension Reduction ((SVD: Singular Value Decomposition, PCA: Principal Component Analysis, LDA: Latent Dirichlet Allocation)), K-Means ((Hierarchical, Density Based, Distance Based)).
Train your algorithm. With your selection from the above list, train your algorithm based on the training dataset.
Make a Prediction. Take the trained algorithm and make a prediction by applying your prediction result to the test dataset. We will be taking that predictive result, or output, and analyzing it next.

Evaluate. Take the test result and compare that against the true values. The act of comparing your predictions against the true values is classified as evaluating your model. Once compared, we see how far off we are (ie. the accuracy score metric tells us how far off). If your evaluation is below your threshold, you should be happy! If your predicted results are extremely off, perhaps you’re seeing an extremely high accuracy score on the first run, you’ll have to go back and check your data and any adjustments made. When you’re not seeing the metrics you’re hoping for, address your concern internally first, check how you cleaned the data to make sure you didn’t miss anything. Try a different algorithm, play around with any functions or new columns or datasets you may have made. Once you can confidently confirm that your process and algorithm are sound, then look externally to source different data- perhaps there’s some open source data that could support your predictive model?

Feature Engineering. If you exhausted all different types of data and exhausted all different types of algorithms, then begin feature engineering. It is best practice to only star feature engineering once you start your second round. Make a copy of your notebook and start to rework your model on your duplicate copy so you can compare and contrast your process difference with your output difference. Creating new features is not a practice to be done lightly so keep working at it, and spend your time evaluating.

Put together your findings and analysis. Communicate your findings in a way that will resonate the most with your given audience. Consider a Keynote, PowerPoint, Google Slides presentation that encapsulates your findings in a meaningful yet digestible way for your business counterparts to best synthesize all the work that’s been done.
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Product Designer @ Meta Reality Labs. UX Lead Instructor @ General Assembly. LA based.
